title: 112_s3077
content: The Act is titled the "Pro Football Hall of Fame Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings related to the subject matter. The Pro Football Hall of Fame's mission is to honor individuals who have made outstanding contributions to professional football, preserve historic documents and artifacts, educate the public about the sport's origin and promote its positive values. The Hall of Fame opened on September 7, 1963 with a charter class of 17 players. The Pro Football Hall of Fame opened on September 7, 1963 with a charter class of 17 players, coaches, and contributors, including legends like Sammy Baugh, Red Grange, and Jim Thorpe. There are currently 273 members inducted into the Hall of Fame, each represented by a bronze bust, a Hall of Fame gold jacket, and a Hall of Fame ring. The Pro Football Hall of Fame, opened in 1963, has 273 members represented by a bronze bust, a gold jacket, and a ring. The museum has welcomed nearly 9 million visitors and undergone multiple expansions and renovations. The Pro Football Hall of Fame has undergone multiple expansions and renovations, leading to a 118,000-square-foot facility. It houses the world's largest collection on professional football, including over 20,000 artifacts and 20 million pages of documents. The museum attracts nearly 15 million visitors annually. The Pro Football Hall of Fame houses over 20,000 artifacts and 20 million pages of documents, including nearly 3 million photographic images. It reaches a worldwide audience of nearly 15 million people annually through various channels such as visitors to the museum, televised events, the Hall of Fame's website, and educational outreach programs. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins weighing 8.359 grams, with a diameter of 0.850 inches, and containing 90% gold. Additionally, $1 silver coins will be minted weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, and containing 90% silver. The $1 silver coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. Half-dollar clad coins will weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches, and be minted to specific specifications. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items, minted to specific specifications for half-dollar coins. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items, minted to specific specifications for half-dollar coins. Design of coins. The coins minted under this Act will be emblematic of professional football, with specific design requirements including inscriptions of value, year, and various words. The design will be selected by the Secretary after consultation. The design for the coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single United States Mint facility during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2016. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted before issuance. The Secretary will accept prepaid orders for coins minted under this Act at a reasonable discount before issuance. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. All sales of coins issued under this Act include surcharges of $35 per $5 coin, $10 per $1 coin, and $5 per half-dollar coin. Surcharges received are promptly paid to the Pro Football Hall of Fame for construction and renovation of facilities. The Hall of Fame is subject to audits. The Pro Football Hall of Fame receives surcharges from the sales of commemorative coins for construction and renovation of facilities. The Hall of Fame is subject to audits as per the requirements of the United States Code. Additionally, there is a limitation on the number of commemorative coin programs that can be issued in a calendar year. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to limit the number of commemorative coin programs issued in a calendar year to avoid exceeding the annual limitation set by the United States Code.
